verses.text: Then all the Israelites from Dan to Beersheba, including the land of Gilead, came out, and the congregation gathered together as one man before the Lord in Mizpah.
verses.comment: The phrase 'as one man' is a Hebrew idiom meaning united in decision.

verses.text: The chiefs of all the people of the tribes of Israel took their places in the assembly of the people of God: four hundred thousand men on foot who drew the sword.
Now the tribe of Benjamin heard that the Israelites had gone up to Mizpah. The Israelites said, 'Tell us, how did this evil happen?'
The Levite, the husband of the woman who was murdered, answered, 'I came to Gibeah of Benjamin, I and my concubine, to spend the night.'
'And the men of Gibeah rose against me, and surrounded the house at night, intending to kill me, and they violated my concubine, and she died.'
'So I took my concubine and cut her in pieces, and sent her throughout the territory of Israel's inheritance, because they had done a disgraceful and wicked thing in Israel.'
'Behold, all you Israelites, give your advice and counsel here.'
All the people stood up together and said, 'None of us will go to his tent, and none of us will return to his house.'
'Now this is what we shall do to Gibeah: We will go against it by lot.'
verses.comment: Casting lots indicates assigning men by chance.

verses.text: 'We will take ten men out of every hundred throughout the tribes of Israel, and a hundred out of a thousand, and a thousand out of ten thousand, to get food for the people, so that when they come to Gibeah of Benjamin, they may punish it for all the disgraceful act that has been done in Israel.'
verses.comment: This verse details the gathering of supplies for the campaign.

verses.text: So all the men of Israel were gathered against the city, united as one man.
Then the tribes of Israel sent men throughout the tribe of Benjamin, saying, 'What is this wickedness that has happened among you?'
'Now, hand over the worthless men in Gibeah, so that we may put them to death and purge evil from Israel.' But the Benjaminites would not listen to their fellow Israelites.
Instead, the Benjaminites gathered from their towns to Gibeah to go out to battle against the Israelites.
On that day the Benjaminites from their towns gathered, twenty-six thousand men who drew the sword, besides the inhabitants of Gibeah, who mustered seven hundred chosen men.
Among all these troops were seven hundred chosen men who were left-handed; every one of them could sling a stone at a hair and not miss.
verses.comment: 'Left-handed' is noted; accuracy in slinging stones emphasizes their skill.

verses.text: The men of Israel, besides Benjamin, mustered four hundred thousand men who drew the sword; all were men of war.
The Israelites arose and went up to Bethel and asked God, 'Who shall go up first to fight against the Benjaminites?' And the Lord said, 'Judah shall go up first.'
So the Israelites got up in the morning and camped against Gibeah.
And the men of Israel went out to fight against Benjamin and drew up battle lines against them at Gibeah.
Then the Benjaminites came out of Gibeah and struck down twenty-two thousand men of Israel that day.
But the men of Israel took courage and formed the battle line once again in the place where they had arrayed themselves the first day.
And the Israelites went up and wept before the Lord until evening, and they asked the Lord, 'Shall we go up again to fight against our brother Benjamin?' And the Lord said, 'Go up against him.'
verses.comment: The phrase 'our brother Benjamin' highlights the tribal relationship.

verses.text: So the Israelites approached the Benjaminites on the second day.
And Benjamin went out from Gibeah to meet them and struck down eighteen thousand men among the Israelites, all of whom drew the sword.

Then all the Israelites and all the people went up to Bethel and sat there, weeping before the Lord. They fasted that day until evening and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.
And the Israelites asked the Lord (for the ark of the covenant of God was there in those days),

And Phinehas the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, served before it in those days, saying, 'Shall I yet again go out to battle against the sons of Benjamin, my brother, or shall I cease?' The Lord said, 'Go up, for tomorrow I will give them into your hand.'
verses.comment: Phinehas mentioned here is the same as in Numbers and Joshua.

verses.text: And Israel set men in ambush around Gibeah.
On the third day the Israelites went up against the Benjaminites and arranged themselves in formation against Gibeah, as they had done before.

The Benjaminites went out against the people and were drawn away from the city. As before, they began to strike and kill some of the people on the highways, one going up to Bethel and another to Gibeah, and killed about thirty men of Israel.
The Benjaminites said, 'They are defeated before us as before.' But the Israelites said, 'Let us retreat and draw them away from the city toward the highways.'
And all the men of Israel rose up from their place and set themselves in formation at Baal-tamar, and the men in ambush rushed out of their place west of Gibeah.
verses.comment: Baal-tamar is a place near Gibeah.

verses.text: Then ten thousand chosen men from all Israel came against Gibeah, and the battle was fierce; but the Benjaminites did not know that disaster was about to strike them.
The Lord struck Benjamin before Israel, and the Israelites destroyed twenty-five thousand one hundred men of Benjamin who drew the sword that day.
So the Benjaminites saw they were defeated. The men of Israel gave ground to Benjamin, because they relied on those they had set in ambush against Gibeah.
The men in ambush hurried and rushed against Gibeah; the men in ambush spread out and struck the whole city with the edge of the sword.
Now the appointed signal between the men of Israel and the men in ambush was that they should make a great cloud of smoke rise up from the city.
So the men of Israel turned in the battle, and Benjamin began to strike and kill about thirty men of Israel; for they said, 'Surely they are defeated before us as in the first battle.'
But when the cloud of smoke began to rise from the city, Benjamin looked behind them, and behold, the whole city went up in smoke to the sky.
Then the men of Israel turned, and the men of Benjamin were terrified, for they saw disaster had come upon them.

Therefore, they turned their backs before the men of Israel toward the way of the wilderness; but the battle overtook them, and those who came out of the cities destroyed them in the midst of Benjamin.
They surrounded the Benjaminites, pursued them, and easily overtook them from Nohah and as far as Gibeah toward the east.
Eighteen thousand men of Benjamin fell, all of them valiant warriors.
They turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon, but five thousand men were cut down on the highways, and they pursued them closely to Gidom and killed two thousand men of them.
So all who fell of Benjamin that day were twenty-five thousand men who drew the sword, all of them valiant warriors.
verses.comment: Totals from previous verses are summed here.

verses.text: But six hundred men turned and fled toward the wilderness to the rock of Rimmon, and they remained at the rock of Rimmon for four months.

And the men of Israel turned back against the sons of Benjamin and struck them with the sword, both the entire city, the livestock, and everything else they found. They also set on fire all the towns they came to.
verses.comment: The phrase 'everything else they found' is used for clarity in modern English.
